title: The Xbox Chromecast

(man laughing) - Microsoft's Xbox streaming stick is back on the menu as they've recently confirmed they are heading back to the drawing board, ditching last year's design in favor of a new approach for delivering Xbox cloud gaming to users around the world. A Microsoft employee confirmed that they were working on their new device, codename Keystone, not to be confused with the oil pipeline, sweet sweet oil. The Chromecast-like streaming stick aims to bring Xbox gaming to not only those who can afford an Xbox console, but to any and everyone who can afford a high-speed broadband connection - [Speaker 2] Little bit broader. - The streaming stick is Microsoft's push to deliver a more consistent and accessible cloud gaming experience and should be available in the next 12 months. Plus it sounds so much more cozy and friendly you know, to say you're cloud gaming, especially when you're teabagging your enemy's corpse in Valorant. It's so relaxing. - [Speaker 2] I play the game to relax, yeah. - AMD has corrected some power specifications for its Socket AM5 for Ryzen 7000. The company announced that its five-nanometer Ryzen 7000s would have a 170-watt TDP and PPT, which is the highest power the CPU can pull under load. That wasn't great news for AMD fans hoping for ultra-powerful new Ryzen that would blow until awake. (man makes cracking sound) - [Speaker 2] Oh geez. - But it turns out, AMD made a little mistake. AMD issued a correction stating that AM5 supports up to 170-watt TDP with a PPT up to 230 watts, which appears to be more in line with what people were expecting. - [Speaker 2] That's a big PP. - This should, of course, enable considerably more PP, excuse me, performance for high core count CPUs during heavy workloads.
